properties.title: Early Prediction of Left Ventricular Reverse Remodeling in First-Diagnosed Idiopathic Dilated Cardiomyopathy: A Comparison of Linear Model, Random Forest, and Extreme Gradient Boosting
properties.abstract: Left ventricular reverse remodeling (LVRR) is associated with decreased cardiovascular mortality and improved cardiac survival and also crucial for therapeutic options. However, there is a lack of an early prediction model of LVRR in first-diagnosed dilated cardiomyopathy. This single-center study included 104 patients with idiopathic DCM. We defined LVRR as an absolute increase in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) from >10% to a final value >35% and a decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic diameter (LVDd) >10%. Analysis features included demographic characteristics, comorbidities, physical sign, biochemistry data, echocardiography, electrocardiogram, Holter monitoring, and medication. Logistic regression, random forests, and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were, respectively, implemented in a 10-fold cross-validated model to discriminate LVRR and non-LVRR, with receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves and calibration plot for performance evaluation. LVRR occurred in 47 (45.2%) patients after optimal medical treatment. Cystatin C, right ventricular end-diastolic dimension, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), left atrial dimension, left ventricular posterior wall dimension, systolic blood pressure, severe mitral regurgitation, eGFR, and NYHA classification were included in XGBoost, which reached higher AU-ROC compared with logistic regression (AU-ROC, 0.8205 vs. 0.5909, p = 0.0119). Ablation analysis revealed that cystatin C, right ventricular end-diastolic dimension, and HDL-C made the largest contributions to the model. Tree-based models like XGBoost were able to early differentiate LVRR and non-LVRR in patients with first-diagnosed DCM before drug therapy, facilitating disease management and invasive therapy selection. A multicenter prospective study is necessary for further validation.

properties.information: Available in Supplementary materials: Supplementary Table 1 and Supplementary Figure 1-4.

properties.description: To develop an early predictive model for left ventricular reverse remodeling (LVRR) in patients with first-diagnosed idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) using clinical and echocardiographic data.

A single-center study was conducted including 104 patients with idiopathic DCM. Models like logistic regression, random forests, and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were implemented with a 10-fold cross-validated model.
LVRR occurred in 45.2% of patients after optimal treatment.
The XGBoost model outperformed logistic regression with an AU-ROC of 0.8205 versus 0.5909.
The tree-based models showed better accuracy in predicting LVRR, aiding in the early identification of non-responders to therapy.

properties.title: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)
properties.description: Significant cause of heart failure and heart transplantation, with a high mortality rate.

properties.title: Left Ventricular Reverse Remodeling (LVRR)
properties.description: Improvements in DCM condition linked to better outcomes.

properties.title: Historical Treatments for DCM
properties.description: Include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, β-blockers, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists.

properties.title: Theoretical Foundations
properties.description: Potential of machine learning models in predictive analytics for DCM.

properties.title: Importance of Research
properties.description: Early prediction of LVRR could improve management strategies for DCM.

properties.title: Gaps in Research
properties.description: Challenges in prognostic stratification in early DCM phases and limited use of prediction models.

nodes.label: Predictors: Cystatin C, Right ventricular end-diastolic dimension, HDL-C
Suggested Improvements: Large sample prospective study
Interpretation
nodes.content: The study shows that ensemble tree models like XGBoost perform better than traditional regression for predicting left ventricular reverse remodeling (LVRR) in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy. Routine clinical indexes and echocardiography data can be effectively used for prediction.

nodes.label: Implication
nodes.content: Using machine learning models could enhance the early identification of patients less likely to respond to medication, allowing more precise management and risk evaluation, potentially leading to improved therapeutic decision-making.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.content: The study is retrospective and single-center, which limits its generalizability. There is a need for prospective studies and external validation. Also, tree-based models tend to have unexplainable feature mechanisms.

nodes.label: XGBoost and random forest models predict LVRR in DCM patients more accurately than logistic regression.
Comparison of XGBoost, random forest, and logistic regression models.
XGBoost and random forest achieved higher AUCs compared to logistic regression.
Study on prediction of LVRR in patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.

properties.description: The study focuses on idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a significant cause of heart failure and heart transplantation. Left ventricular reverse remodeling (LVRR) is an important factor in reducing mortality and improving cardiac function in DCM.

Despite improvements in heart failure treatment, LVRR occurs in only a proportion of DCM patients. Early identification of patients likely to undergo LVRR could improve patient management and therapeutic strategies.

There is a lack of early prediction models for LVRR in patients with first-diagnosed idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy, leading to challenges in prognostic stratification and management of the condition.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.description: The study is a single-center and retrospective study, which may limit the generalizability of the findings.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.description: There is a need for a larger sample prospective study and external validation to provide stronger evidence.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.description: The study focused on predictive performance rather than statistical inference, so no conclusions can be drawn about risk factors.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.description: Compared to linear models, tree-based models may exhibit unexplainable feature mechanisms, complicating interpretation.

properties.description: Tree-based models like XGBoost and Random Forest predict early left ventricular reverse remodeling in idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy more accurately than logistic regression.
Machine learning models (XGBoost, Random Forest, logistic regression) were used to predict LVRR.
The study's retrospective, single-center nature limits generalizability. Focus on model performance without statistical inference about risk factors or mechanisms.
Combining multiple routine clinical indicators into machine learning models enhances prediction and management of DCM, improving early identification.

nodes.non-LVRR: Defined as an absolute increase in LVEF <10%, final value <35%, or a decrease in LVDd <10%

nodes.label: Evaluation
